awd_titl_txt: Forecasting Risk in Rapidly Changing Urban Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
In the year 2008 urban dwellers for the first time ever outnumbered rural ones. By 2030 twice as many people will live in cities than in 1970. This shift in population has also led to a shift in the landscape of risk, with cities becoming the major source of global risk. Current risk assessment models fall short in characterizing the spatial and temporal dynamics of the urban environments in terms of rapidly changing local exposure and vulnerability. We propose to develop a quantitative approach for forecasting risk in rapidly changing urban environments. The two main components of the proposed approach are (a) dynamic time-dependent exposure models and (b) time dependent vulnerability model that consider the main processes influencing the vulnerability of the built environment over time: structural deterioration, incremental expansion of buildings, and evolving building practices. The models and advanced technologies to be developed through this research include stochastic spatial and temporal exposure methods, novel remote-sensing based techniques for urban analysis, statistical pattern recognition methods and probabilistic analysis of incremental building expansion and vulnerability to enable risk forecast over time.

The proposed research will enable risk forecasts that are consistent with the population and urban building growth patterns of regions exposed to extreme events. The tools developed will enable policy-makers, municipal governments and planners to take steps towards reducing future risk. Research results will be integrated into current risk assessment models, such HAZUS, the software used by FEMA and the Department of Homeland Security for planning and managing disasters, and the Global Earthquake Model (GEM is a worldwide nonprofit earthquake consortium developing open source tools for earthquake hazard and risk assessment) that will enable them to better model and forecast the complex dynamics of urban risk. Numerous components of the research will further be part of a new Stanford interdisciplinary undergraduate class on urban risk, taught by research team members. The project team has a strong record in working with underrepresented groups and actively participates in Stanford's Engineering Diversity Program that provides teaching, research and mentoring opportunities for students from underrepresented groups. Undergraduates will be included in the project through NSF's REU program and Stanford's research to undergraduate students program supported by the Vice Provost on Undergraduate Education (VPUE).

por.por_cntn:
Forecasting Risk in Rapidly Changing Urban

Environments

The main objective of this project was to develop a quantitative approach for forecasting risk in rapidly changing urban environments. The two main components of the approach included: (a) Modeling future exposure that captures urban in population growth, expansion and densification; and (b) Modeling the vulnerability of expanding infrastructure in an urban region. The aim was to develop forecasting models for data-sparse environments; therefore the model uses minimal input requirements of historical satellite/aerial images and basic demographic information. Results were assessed for their statistical consistency in terms of hazard exposure, rather than refined spatial accuracy. Modeling future vulnerability focused on capturing the changes in fragility of the built environment over time and identifying the main factors that influence these changes such as: structural deterioration, incremental expansion of buildings through increases in height and floor plan, and evolving building practices.

The following objectives were achieved:

A new model was developed for dynamic risk assessment for a region subjected to earthquakes. The dynamic components of the earthquake risk assessment model include: (a) the development of fragility functions for incremental construction of buildings resulting in time dependent fragility functions that describe the probability of damage or collapse as functions of the severity of ground shaking and height of the structure and (b) considerations of population and infrastructure growth over a region in forecasting future risk exposure and loss.

Fragility functions for incremental expansion of housing units, typical of majority of developing countries in the world, were developed using analytical simulations of such structures. Building model typologies were developed for this purpose and the change from one type to another type of structure was tracked. Figure 1 shows the typologies defined for the model. A Markov probability model was developed for the transitioning from one building typology to another (e.g. one story in-fill masonry to two story in-fill masonry). Figure 2. Shows an example set of fragilities for a structure increasing in number of stories over time. It can be observed that the fragility of the structure increases significantly when the height increases from on to three to four stories with the largest change seen when going from two to three and four stories.  

Data on building densification was obtained primarily through analysis of satellite imagery from the past 30 years. For that purpose the building distribution in Kathmandu, Nepal were investigated. In this case, the increase in spatial growth was tracked and modeled.

There were many significant findings from this project. The most significant are:

  • Forecasting risk over future time periods requires consideration of the dynamic changes in population, the number of buildings and the transition of buildings from one typology to another in order to have a realistic risk estimates.
  • While it had long been speculated that the risk over time is likely to increase, prior models were inadequate in capturing the dynamic changes of the infrastructure and populations exposed to the hazard. It was demonstrated, with the use of the advanced dynamic risk models that there is an exponential growth of the risk with time.
  • It was also demonstrated that if mitigation activities are introduced and enforced the risk trajectory could be changed and significantly lowered.
  • From the fragility analysis of different housing typologies it was demonstrated that when structures increase from one to two stories the probability of collapse increases significantly. When the growth is from two to three or four stories the vulnerability of these taller structures becomes extreme almost ensuring their collapse even under moderate grown shaking. These results clearly demonstrate the need for controlled development and for putting policies in place that will limit building vertical expansion. Just as important is the need to enforce such policies to prevent the construction of highly vulnerable structures. Figures 3 and 4 show the risk trajectory over time for Kathmandu, Nepal.

Research findings have been widely presented at national and international conferences, workshops, forums and panels. Five journal papers have been published and one has been accepted for publication. Two students were partially supported with funds from this project and have completed their PhD degrees. A third doctoral student has been working on this research topic in the last six months of the project.

As a result of the research and activities under this project a new Stanford Urban Resilience Initiative (SURI: http://web.stanford.edu/group/urbanresilience/cgi-bin/wordpress/) was started at the John A. Blume Earthquake Engineering Center at Stanford. A workshop inaugurating the initiative was held in October 2016. Two new courses have also been initiated at Stanford at the graduate level: CEE 209B: Disaster Risk and International Development Seminar and CEE 308: Topics in Disaster Resilience Research.
